titleStmt.title: On the Words────Brother Protestants and Christians──────

lg.l: An Inundation (says the Fable)
O'erflow'd a Farmers Barn and Stable
Whole Stacks of Hay & Ricks of Corn
Were down the sudden Current born
While Things of heterogeneous Kind
Together Sail'd with Tide & Wind
The honest wheat forgot his Pride
And Sail'd with Litter, Side by Side
Uniting All, to Shew their Amity
As in a general Calamity──
A Ball of new drop't Horses dung
Mingling with Apples on the Throng,
Said to a Pippen large and Prim
See Brother, how we Apples swim
Thus Lamb renow'd for cutting Corns
A proffer'd Fee from Ratcliff scorns
Not for the world──we Doctors Brother
Must take no Fees from One another──
Thus to a Dean, some Curate sloven
Subscribes──Dṛ Sir your Brother loving─
Thus all the Footmen, Shooe Boys, Porters
About Sṭ James's cry──We Courtiers────
Thus Horace in the House will prate
Sir, We the ministers of State────
Thus at the Bar, that Booby B──
(Tho half a Crown o'erpays his Sweat's worth)
Who knows in Law not Text nor Margent,
Calls Singleton his Brother Serjeant.
And thus Fanatick Saints tho neither in
Doctine or Dicipline, our Brethern
Are Brother Protestants & Christians
But in no other Sense, than Nature
Has made a Rat our fellow Creature
Lice from your Body suck their Food
But is a Louse your Flesh and Blood?
Tho born of human Filth & Sweet, It.Cannot be said, man did beget It────
The Maggots in your nose and Chin
As well may claim you for their Kin.
But Criticks may object──why not
Since Lice are Brethren to a Scot
Which made our Swarm of Sects determine
Employments for their Brother Vermin
But be they English Irish, scottish
What Protestant can be so sottish
(While o'er the Church these Clouds are gath' overering)
To call a Swarm of Lice his Brethren
As Moses by divine Advice
in Egypt Turn'd the Dust to lice
And as our Sects by all Descriptions
Have Hearts more harden'd than Egyptians
As from the trodden Dust They Spring
And turn'd to Lice infest the King
For pity sake it were but just,
A Rod should turn them back to Dust
Let men in high or holy Stations
Be proud of owning such Relations
Let Courtiers hug them in their Bosom
As if they were afraid to lose them
Whilst I with humble Job had rather
Say to Corruption──Thou'rt my Father811-410P
